He asked whether Khan Sahib Yusuf Kanoo was prepared to take up the agency of their steamers. 3* :4r. Xaaeko also, I bellewe, saw a Persian merchant, Baji Muhammad l&yib Phunji, presumably on the same business. 4. A copy is enclosed of an extract taken by Khan fahib Yusuf Kanoo from an illustrated book called 'Outline of the Mitsubishi Enterprises, 1932'. He xms been promised a 1934 copy. 5. Mr. Raneko, who was accompanied by a Persian interpreter Mr* Abul Caeitt Babir, is-said to be proceeuing to Tehran tia Mohcusmerah. 6. Ho one is allowed to take up steamer agencies without the pemiBBion of the Bahrain Government ana i should be gr&teful for orders as to the attitude which should be aaopted should Khan Sahib Yusuf Kanoo or anyone else apply for the Agency of a Japanese steamer line. v i 7. It is probably possible for me to arrange for the Bahrain Government to refuse permission to anyone to take up an /agencyI 2 . i agency and a certain amount of local discouragement say be feasible. But it seems hardly desirable to embark on such opposition unless it is the intention of C-OYernment to keep the Japanese line out in the same way as was done in the case of the Kussi&n line. / Lieut-Ooionel* Political Agent., Bahrain. /Confident ial. iLL o A m JL A P 2J±*. Bashirs* Uo:Q/^CZ oat eel tae 2 'dih April 1334 , rj ixprea* -ettar C/ 4 S 4 April HStn, 1934 . luauf Aaaoo lias sent no letter dated April 33 rd icopj enclosed; regarding the trsiaa and Japan Trading Cospanj Limited. 3 * It is requested that, if there is no objection, enquiries mj be made to ascertain whether the firm is a reputable one. 3 . i ao not toow whether ti.e. fact that the firm niiiYo an office (apparently th« head office) in Tehran is lively to prove objectionable or troublesome. /) 'uieut-Oclonel, Political Agent., .oaurain.f Confidential * D.0.Mo:C/463. Political Agency, Bahrain,the 2^th April 1934. Will you kinaly refer to my Express Letter No: s C/462 dated the 29th April 1934 about Yusuf Kanoo and the agency for 'The Persia and Japan Trading Company Limited'. 2. Yusuf Kanoo came to see me today (April 29th) and said that he would refuse the agency if we wished him to do so, though it would mean profit to himself and though not to take it would merely mean someone else getting.it. 3. He asked me to enquire whether there was any objection to his taking up the agency. 4. It is impossible to stop Japanese goods coming in at their low prices, and I would sooner that Yusuf Kanoo held the agency (assuming the firm to be a reputable one) than other possible aspirants. 5. I should be grateful if you would let me know what reply to give to Yusuf Kanoo. £f The Honourable Lieut-Colonel T.C.Fowle.C.3.E., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire.[A , This is m ORIGINAL MESSAGE, sent by 'post to save telegraphic expense and undue use of the wires, but intended to be treated, on receipt, with the same expedition as if it had been telegraphed. To save time and formalities it is worded and signed as if it had been so despatched,] From AIR miL. political Resident, Bushire. To Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Repeated to She Department of overseas Trade Leaden His Majesty*s Minister, Tehran# J f a £ n P®« Simla* Secretary of state ^ for India, Leaden# ^ political Agent, laSmift# lo. Ho.d # o.T.(B.S). 8 Bated Bushire, the 7th Ray 1954* subjectJapanese Trade in the Persian Gulf# I enclose a copy of an Express letter from the political Agent, Bahrain no# a/462, dated the 29th APril 1934# 2# in a separate communication colonel Loch informed me that Mr#xusuf Kano© had asked him whether he should take up the Agency for the Persia and japan Trading Company Lifted, and went on to say that he,{iir*Yusuf Kanoc), would refuse the Agency if we wished him to do, though it would mean if he did not take it somebody else would# 3# Colonel Loch himself would sooner that Mr.yusuf Kanoo h@l^. the Agency than ether possible aspirants# ECS 3P—ISSfiS&P**- (M-I821)—S7-C-22—«.Jf f ,CC0. p.t.0*■i . siace Mr.xusuf Kaaoc is a gccd friend of the political Agenoy* he was made a oozamander of the Indian Bapir# some years ago, I agree tbat it would be better for various reasons -that he should hold the Agency but before advising colonel looh finally i would be glad to be informed urgently, since fhe Persia and Japan trading Company Limited will doubtless want an answer from ur» Ttnsuf Kanoc as soon as possible, as to the standing of this fin* Sd/- T.C.Fowie. political Resident in the Persian oulf.GOVERNMENT OE INDIA, —— Department, [N, B\ - his is an ORIGINAL MESSAGE, sent by post to sare telegraphic expense ana unaue use of the wires, but intended to be treated? on receipt,' with the same expedition as if it had been telegraphed. To sare lime and formalities it is worded and signed as if it had been so despatched.} From Political o:- l f Ut' of Plate for isoia f ^ondoa* Bj Air ail* 3 to tko GQVariXiikmX of ir*dia, No* fa/ 1 * V ^ «1 > Dated jofi Air Mail* 4. gahmia Oil* eiroleas* D«p&rt«at»s latter oi 1034^ to India Office, {India Gfiioe /34 ^ 11th)* 2* It aea&s posaitl# U*at diiubi^lu iniereata ar« what was reported in Express letter Ia:C/4M April ESth as ’’Mitsubishi .jaterprises 7 ^ m tdat the despatch of litre barrels of crude oil jssj well haire boon the reside vl Nsawto’s tisit to .Bahrain* landed on tae idud April load vjso dospato&^d on the 31 si April T o Sd/- G.Loch, Bieut-iolonel, Political Bahrain.. s. e. MFP—785S&P—(M-1014}—18- 8 -33—2,00,000.INDIA OFFICE, LONDON, Forwarded with the compliments of the Secretary, Political Department, India Office. A copy has been sent to by ~ Mail. 2732/ I P.Z. 33 68 /34. 26048/1934. immediate. DEPARTMEFT OF OVERSEAS TRADE, 35, OLD QUEEF STREET, LONDON, S.W.l. 18th May, 1934. Sir, With reference to the two express letters, D. O.T. (B.S. )No.8 and D. 0. T. (O.T. ) No.3, of May 7th, with enclosures, addressed by the Political Resident, Bushire, to the Department of Overseas Trade, copies of which have been sent direct to the India Office, on the subject of prospective Japanese agencies to be taken up by Yusuf Kanoo for (a) The Persia and Japan Trading Co.Ltd., and (b) the Steamship Line of w Mitsubishi Enterprises w , I am directed by Lt.Col.J. Colville to state, for the information of Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare, that, in general terns, this case is one of a respectable local firm asking whether they may take up competitive agencies for foreign goods. In the analogous case of Soviet goods, it was decided that no objection could be offered since, if one firm fails to take up the agency, another will do so. 2• Colonel Colville therefore proposes, subject to the concurrence of Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare, to inform the Political Resident that, for the reason given, he should raise no objection to these Japanese agencies being undertaken by Yusuf Kanoo. 3* ith reference to the last paragraph of Colonel Fowle 1 s despatch D.O.T. {B.S. )No. 8 of May 7th, Colonel Colville feels that it does not fall within the functions of the Department of Overseas Trade to procure a/ The Under Secretary of State, India Office. Hi/ a. status report on a Japanese firm; - the grounds, if any, for such an enquiry are political rather than ccmmercial. The local firm, having decided to represent a Japanese trading entity, must do so at their own risk. He therefore does not propose to take steps to obtain such a report. 4. A copy of this letter has been sent to the Foreign Office and the Bocrd of Trade. I am, etc., (Sgd.) Cecil C.Farrer, for the Comptroller General.mutfHK ll IK Telegram:- XX. From:- Secretary of State for India. To:- Political Resident, Bushire. No:1340. Repeated:- Government of India. 1341. Political Agent, Bahrain. No:- 1342. Bated:- 23rd (received 24th) May 1534. Your two Nxpress Letters of May 7th to B.O.T. Japanese trade in Bahrain. His Majesty T s Government see no objection on political grounds to Kanoo accepting Japanese agency. B.O.T feel that it is not their province to procure status report on . iiMi—i—iiiwuini iniiininirwr foreign firm but it is understood that Mitsubishi Enter prises are well known Japanese concern. /s ^ ^ r letaxandum.CONFIDENTIAL. No - C/289 of 1934. The Hon ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf presents his pliments to 1. The political Agent, Kuwait. 2# The rolitical Agent, Bahrain* com* TO'(l) only To(2) only r , v . k r and has the honour to transmit to him a copy of the undermentioned docu* naent (s).with the request that ( a report may be made on the activities of Mr.Kuninosuke ( Nakatani• (x the Residency Agent may be instructed to submit a report \ on the activities of Mr.Kuninosuke Nakatani. b. In particular it would be interesting to know with whom and in what goods he does business. Office of the olitical HesidenDatcd...23rd temper. 1934. ■ in the Persian Gulf, Camp,Kuwait. ” i | Reference to previous correspondence: Description of Enclosure. Name and Date. Subject. Telegram dated the 21st September 1934 from the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Political Depart ment. Telegram No.T/164 dated the 23rd September 1934 to the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, iolitical Depart* Visit of Japanese trade representative to Kuwait and Dibai. ment.Telegram G.T.C. From Government of Bombay, Political Department, Bombay. To Political Resident, at Kuwait. Unnumbered. Dated 21st (received 23rd)September 1934. (Relayed under Bushire telegram unnumbered dated the 22nd September 1934). Mr. KUNINOSUKB NAKATANI, Japanese subject, representative of Japan Cotton Trading Company, desires to proceed to Kuwait and Dibai on firm’s business, will stay there about a fortnight. May visas be granted. - Secretary to Government of Bombay, Political Department-'■mail The Secretary to the Hou’ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf presents his compliments to The Political Agent, Muscat. The Political Agent, Bahraini The Political Agent, Kuwait. and is directed to transmit to him a copy of the undermentioned documents. British Residency and Consulate-General, BIT SHI RE. r Dated.. .th e • ? - -•■October •*•3 4 • Reference to previous correspondence : Description of Enclosure. Name and Date. Subject. Extract from Diary No.6/8 of H.B.M*s Consulate for Khuzistan, Ahwaz, for the months June,July and August 1934. Japanese trade interests in the Persian Gulf and Persia. \ \Extract from Diary ^*6/6 of Consulate for Khusi8tan ft .rihw&z, for the months of June* July and august l9o4* m !»«»*> «IMW 4* 175. Japanese Interests. A Japanese ship 'J&nkTm Maru w arrived Moiiaamrah from Osaka via the Gulf 1-orte on the C7 th June* Ghe dis» -charged 705 packages of general cargo. 'There is a rumour that another Japanese shipping oompahy is to oe established in the Persian Gulf to compete with the existing one. the Agency for Karachi, Basra and Moh&mmerah is to bo given to a British Indian firm named Haji Jetha Bhy Gokal and© SECRET , D,C*No.C/428-9/8. The 17th July 1939* Is there say strong reejson v/by the Bahrein Goverrunent should not double or quadruple their norms! customs tariff on goods of Japanese origin ? 2. I had the impression that this question had been discussed before, but my office is unable to show me any papers. In any case, even if there were any previous discussion^ it must have been in a very different international atmosphere, 3# There is little doubt that even the vaguest hint would be sufficient for His Highness and his Government to tale actionf and though obviously the price of cheap gimerack articles would go up we do not think that the public would object to a special tariff on goods dumped here by the detested Japanese. The Honourable Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Trenchard Fowle, KCIE., CBI3. f Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, B tf 3 H I R E. Yours sincerely, /!SBOUST. D» Q« m ♦ 0/ 501 « Office of the Political Resident in the Persian Qulf> Gamp, Shiraz* Dated the 5th August, 1939* v >ls Gould you please refer to your demi-official letter iio • C/428-9/8, dated the l7th July 1939, suggesting that the Bahrain Government should put a penal customs tariff on goods of Japanese origin. B. There are various reasons against this step, of which the most important is perhaps that His Ma3esty f s Government who, except for the Chinese, are the party suffering most from Japanese aggression, have not asked Bahrain Government to take any such action as you propose, nor have His Majesty’s Government themselves imposed any discriminatory tariff so far against Japanese goods. When and if His Majesty’s Government do this it will be time to consider whether the Bahrain Govern ment should follow their example. In the meantime there is no need, I think, for the Bahrain Government to be 'plus royalirte que le roi*» and I am pretty sure that His Majesty’s Government*s attitude would be the same as shown by their ^Aj, w> ^ telegram itfo.3635, dated the 12th November 1935, in the case of sanctions against Italy, which in that case they themselves had actually applied* 3. Another disadvantage would be that the price of Japanese goods would, of course, rise considerably. Ihe people in Bahrain who would suffer would be the general public, who are poor and therefore purchase these goods in preference to better class articles at higher prices. Whatever may be the feelings of the Shaikh and his family against the Japanese, I do not / imagine H.Wei ghtman Esquire, ICS.» Political Agent, Bahrain, C/o Postmaster, Ziarat.2 < imagine that the average Bahraini has any particular animus against them or, at any rate, any animus which is at all likely to outweigh the blow to his pocket* 'ihe unpopularity of such measures would react not only against the Bahrain Government, but against ourselves who would be regarded, and rightly, as the instigators of the measure*30 P.A As ordered I informed Khan Sahib Yusuf bin Ahmad Kanu on Saturday the 26th May 1934 at 5 p.m. that, in connection with his letter which he wrote to P.A. asking if there was any object ion to his taking the agency of the Persia and Japan Trading Company, there is no objection. Khan Sahib Yusuf Kanu has asked me to convey his grateful thanks to you. 27.5.34/ cu will remember that before I left Bahrain we discussed the possibility of Imposing a special customs tariff on goods of Japanese origin. I enclose herewith for your private information a cc Py fu y letter of the 17th July on this subject and of Sir -iy --Zl ' ; i-renchard* s reply which I have just received. 2. Personally I do not feel we ought to leave the matter where it is. To the objection raised in paragraph 2 of Sir Irenehard* a letter there is the obvious reply that since Bahrain exports nothing to Japan (not even oil these days) there is not the same commercial objection to a penal customs rate on Japanese goods in Bahrain as there would be in England, since the Japanese themselves cannot take retaliatory action* 3. As far as I remember the Iraqis have insisted on Japan taking Iraq exports up to © certain percentage of the value of Japanese imports into Iraq. It is an amusing - but scarcely profitable - speculation to wonder what would happen if Bahrain insisted on Japan taking Bahrain pearls up to 60 per cent of the value of Japanese imports into Bahrain t However there is no point in pursuing that idea. What we might consider, I think, C. DaIrymple Belgrave, Esquire, .Adviser to the Bahrain Government, in /- Bahrain.! in oraer to meet the objection raised in Sir Trenchard*s third paragraph, is the imposition of a penal customs rate on Japanese articles describable as luxury articles, and on Japanese cement* Perhaps you would think over this in the course of the next month or so and we could have a discussion about it when I get back* 4* Will you please treat this as strictly private and personal ? Yours sincerely,

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 9/8 Japanese trade activities in the Persian Gulf'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically. There are file notes at the end, on folios 30-34. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 34; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-34; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence sent and received by the Political Agent at Bahrain concerning Japanese trade interests in the Persian Gulf; in particular, the correspondence concerns a request by Yusuf Kanoo to operate as agent in Bahrain for the sale of goods of Mitsubishi Enterprises.There is a letter in Arabic, with English translation, sent to the Resident Agent at Sharjah.
